column1: An intrauterine device (IUD) is a small plastic T-shaped device used for birth control.
This procedure can cause discomfort and pain, but not all women have the same side effects.
During insertion, you may feel: - Little pain and some discomfort - Cramping and pain - Dizzy or light-headed Some women have cramps and backaches for 1 to 2 days after insertion.
- A rare chance the IUD may make a hole in the uterine wall when it is inserted.
If you are sensitive to pain in your vagina or cervix, ask for a local anesthetic to be applied before the procedure starts.
But you should use a backup form of birth control, such as a condom, for the first week.
